text.p: These are the leading stories in the Malawi press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Malawi Deputy Police Chief Kennedy Chirambo is expected to appear before High Court in Lilongwe, the administrative capital, to answer charges of "contempt of court" for ordering re-arrest of four Nigerians after they were granted bail by a magistrate court.

- Malawi schools open today amid threats of low quality education from Teachers Union of Malawi (TUM) unless government implements the Teaching Service Commission, said Secretary General Benjamin Ndalama.
- Wives of Malawi Army soldiers on Sunday received seven million kwacha ($467,000) in loans for their businesses from Small Enterprises Development Organisation of Malawi (SEDOM).
- The Malawi Congress Party (MCP) has called for Health Minister Ziliro Chibambo's immediate resignation for retrenching all surgical specialists at Lilongwe Central Hospital.
- A group of prominent clerics including Catholic Bishops will this morning hold talks with opposition Alliance for Democracy (AFORD) in a bid to discuss the country's political crisis.
- Political parties represented in parliament have indicated they would favour a review of the constitution as a solution to the country's political problems since the current one has many loopholes.
- Two people died last week at Lilongwe Central Hospital due to absence of surgical specialists who have since been retrenched by government.
- Deputy Inspector general of Police Kennedy Chirambo risks arrest for contempt of court after he ignored a court order granted to bail two Nigerians on December 10.
